stimulusHtml:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.


A physiologist is interested in studying the exercise habits of workers from a certain large city. The physiologist visited a gym in the city and asked members of the gym to respond to the question, “Do you usually exercise before you go to work?”

(a) Explain how the physiologist’s sampling method might have introduced bias and describe how the bias might affect the point estimate of p, the proportion of all workers from the city who would respond “yes” to the question.

Suppose that 22% of workers from the city exercise before going to work. Let E represent the number of workers in a random sample of ten workers from the city who exercise before going to work. The graph shows the probability distribution of E.

(b) Calculate and interpret the expected value of E.
(c) Describe a simulation process that could be conducted to estimate the value of P(E≥4).

A manager at a company in the city is interested in examining whether the 2,700 employees of the company have different exercise habits from the overall population of workers from the city. A random sample of 50 employees will be selected from the company and each employee will be asked to report whether they usually exercise before going to work.

(d) If the researcher uses a stratified random sampling procedure to select the sample, identify an effective variable on which to stratify. Explain your reasoning.

Assume the conditions for inference are met. A 90 percent confidence interval for the proportion of all employees at this company who would report that they usually exercise before going to work was computed to be 0.260±0.102.

(e) Does the confidence interval provide convincing statistical evidence that employees at this company have different exercise habits from the overall population of workers from the city? Justify your answer.
